reviewText:
Background: I first played this game on a 486 back in the 90s.

This is a great game, but if you compare it to new games, or even a Doom type game it will look very primitive.  You will also be missing the point of how important this was to the history of FPS games.

The game is simple to pick up, hard to master.  To master the toughest difficulty, I am Death Incarnate, you will need some good FPS skills, good choice of knowing when to use each type of weapon and some level knowledge.    The game is also has a good element of skill to it.  The closer you are, the more likely you are to hit as well as get hit.  You can also take a lot more damage up close so you have to be careful going through doorways and in tight spaces.

There are secrets to find, treasure to pick up, par times to bet, Hitler to kill, and a ton of Nazis to mow down on the way.  The game even lets you hold MORE THAN TWO GUNS AT ONCE! :P  However there are only two weapons you will use long term, the grey machine gun which has great economy with the bullets and a decent rate of fire.  There is also the gatling gun which never gets tiring to use.  It has an amazing sound, an amazing red flash on the screen and watching your ammo quickly depleting makes you realise just how powerful it is.

For a perfectionist this game is great, at the end of each level you are rated on what % you kill, what % of the secrets you found and how much of of the nazi loot you confiscated. Back in the 90s I spent a lot of time carefully walking around every wall holding down space waiting to hear the magical sound of a new secret passage opening.  The the excitement of wondering if I've found just a block of ammo, or maybe a crapload of treasure.

The game has 6 episodes, each with 9 levels + a secret level on each episode.

Anyway, somehow I was able to sneak away from normal kid study hall to go hang out with my buddy every day, and because his school assignments were handed to him on a silver platter, we had all sorts of time to play ‚Äúeducational games‚Äù on the school‚Äôs nifty Macintosh computer. Back in those days Mac wasn‚Äôt exactly known for having enjoyable games, and the school had enough sense to purchase only games that no one would want to play. Titles such as ‚ÄúWacky Jacks‚Äù, ‚ÄúSim Tower‚Äù, and ‚ÄúDr. Quandry‚Äù were the 3 gems we had to choose from.

Why all of this non-Wolfenstein related talk? Well I‚Äôm getting to that, you see, while the educational powers that be may have done their best to sanitize our academic computer usage of any fun, they overlooked one small detail. One of the games came with a demo to Wolfenstein3D. We loaded that thing up, and study hall forevermore turned into a Nazi bloodbath. reviewText:
Wolfenstein 3D is one of the earliest 3D FPS games ever made. You play as BJ Blazkowicz who is trapped in a Nazi prison and must escape through maze like environments. Through some unexplained reason he starts off with a pistol, which is fine considering the story is barely existent. This Steam version features the extra 3 prequel mission packs that double the amount of episodes from the base game. The prequel episodes are Episode 4-6 but I suggest starting off at Episode 1 since the prequel missions are significantly harder. There are four difficultly settings overall. The first two feature much less enemies so you will not be worrying that much about health or ammo and as a result make it feel more like a puzzle game. The other 2 feature tougher enemies and much more enemies occasionally placed in rather  inconvenient areas. Both offer completely viable playstyles.

The gameplay feels more tactical than just running and gunning. A single well placed bullet can take up to 80% of your health and you will not be able to dodge since the game takes a realistic approach as to how fast bullets go through the air. So even the lowest of grunts can kill you if he has a faster trigger finger than you. Luckily they suffer the storm trooper effect of being unlikely to hit anything more than a couple of feet away and even if they manage to the bullet damage is decreased the further away you are. Which leads you to playing very carefully, scouting the area instead of simply rushing through hallways like a supersoilder. There is a 99 ammo limit  which seems like a lot but all the weapons share the same ammunition which leads to more depth as you decide which of the 3 guns are best suited for each situation.

The 3 weapons are as follows, a starting pistol which is very effective close range but puts you in risk of a fatal shot, a submachine gun which is pretty solid in medium range but uses up more ammo and a chaingun that annihilates enemies but burns through precious ammunition quickly. There is also a weak knife that you won't be using except in the most dire of situations.  You start off with 100% health and can be regenerated by multiple items including health packs, turkey legs, and dog food. It is a rather strange feeling when you are on the verge of death and are overjoyed to see dog food. Though the real joy comes when you push against a wall and it slides open to reveal much needed supplies and nazi treasure. While we are on the topic of ill gotten goods I should mention there is a scoring and live system. Killing enemies and finding treasure generate points and when you get enough you will receive an extra life that puts you at the beginning of the level with just a pistol when you die. Which I find to be rather odd considering there are manual saves but can be useful if you save at a very inopportune time.

Onto graphics. They are very,very outdated, obviously considering the age of the game. But it does negatively effect the experience since all of the walls have the same basic textures which make rooms look basically the same which can be confusing. Added to that problem is the fact that the level design makes no sense. The rooms have no logical rhythm to them and are just randomly stringed together, along with a lack of a map it is needless to say not a game for those that constantly forget where they parked their car. The enemy models look pretty good ranging from German Shepards to Nazi Zombies. There are no ceiling or floor textures either which I didn't find to be much of a problem since most of the game is gray. There are occasional plants and objects thrown about to liven the place up but they may have gone a little overboard with the amount of swastikas and Hitler pictures around. All in all I'd say the 3D effect is awesome but not much else.

The sound in this game is good for the most part. Guns sound powerful and add intensity to the gun fights. As for the enemies I have no idea how good the voice acting is since I do not speak German but they do sound rather comical. Though it is extremely helpful since each enemy have their own audio line when they are alerted to your presence which lets you easily identify the type of enemy and their numbers. The metal bunker doors also have a nice sounding effect when opened and closed letting you know that the enemy is on the look for you. Unfortunately the music is pretty bad and gets annoying after a short amount of time. Strangely enough they saved the only good tracks for Episode 3 and they were never seen again.

Overall this game is very basic with nothing more to do than search the environment and shoot foes which I can see getting unbearably repetitive for some. You will also need a good sense of direction to get much enjoyment from this game. If you can get past that you will find a very fun game which has exhilarating boss fights,  plenty of secrets and tons of missions to play through. It also has cool secret levels including one where you fight the ghosts from Pacman. So buckle up, find a chaingun and show them Nazis that a guy named BJ is no laughing matter!

reviewText:
The father of all First Person Shooters. Although not id Software's first FPS, it certainly paved the way for a long-running succession of amazing games over the years. id's passion for details makes this game a valuable piece in every gamer's collection.

Just imagine that in 1992 all offices in the world still worked on text-only interfaces, However, id Software came out with a game that further extended previous FPS's capabilities, such as 256 colors (instead of 16), textures, incredible sounds, voices, an excellent music that immerses you in the gameplay and sets the perfect mood, and detailed animated sprites for enemies, as well as an amazing level design throughout the whole game that makes you feel as if you were actually within nazi premises, trying to escape. Basic and easy controls, a choice of only 4 weapons (sharing the same ammo) and a nice amount of secret walls and treasure on each level make this game very rewarding and loveable. id's typical sense of humour can be witnessed throughout the complete gameplay in inter-episode texts, the enemies' speech as they see you and as they die, as well as Wolfenstein's famous PacMan secret level, make this game unique and amazing.

Although it is possible to download the game for free, you will be glad to have paid some money for it.

Where would FPSs be nowadays if id Software had pursued a different path and never developed Wolfenstein 3D? Would have another company dared make an incursion into FPSs? Would the 2398 Call of Duties of today exist? Or Half-Life?

Every FPS in the shelf today owes its existance to this game. And you will not regret having played it.

reviewText:
Basically, if you're curious about gaming history and know what you're getting into, this is a pretty entertaining vintage FPS and it's worth a look - but I do mean vintage. If for whatever reason you didn't like DOOM, you'll like this game even less.

This game technically wasn't the first FPS, but it was the first FPS if you catch my drift, and it jumpstarted the genre like lightning ripping through Frankenstein. If you're interested, I would recommend using a sourceport like ECWolf[maniacsvault.net] instead of the DOSBox emulation you get here; Steam's DOSBox emulation for games is generally poor quality. What you're really paying for are the actual game files, so you might as well.


Wolfenstein 3-D, the third game and first FPS in the overall Wolfenstein series, is first and foremost a piece of history and a pretty mechanically simple first-person shooter - at least on the surface. Released via shareware in 1992, it was iD's first FPS and second 'proper hit' after Commander Keen. At the time, its fast, brutal Nazi-killing action was much more shocking to people than many games today: it was simply a new thing back then. This was released before the ESRB even existed, and it says something that iD voluntarily rated their game PC-13 - for Profound Carnage.

You play as B.J. Blazkowicz, World War II Allied agent. You're charged with solo infiltration of Nazi strongholds to hamper their war effort in various ways. This involves, surprise surprise, shooting a good number of Nazis. To put the gameplay itself shortly, it can be fun as a surreal experience and a raw, oftentimes challenging shooter. Given how it's designed, however, it gets old after half an episode of playtime. It's best played in chunks, unless of course you really want to shoot Nazis and steal their treasure - this game is dated as a 25+ year old game would be, and is probably suited for hardier players who can handle frustration to appreciate a classic.


There are 6 episodes of 10 maps each, including each episode's secret map. You navigate the maps, dispatch Nazis, search for keys to progress if you need them, and pick up ammo and health lying on the floor when needed. There's no looking up or down; even the floors and ceilings are a single texture here. Secrets can be found by pushing on the correct wall tiles, and they're still satisfying to find more than 20 years later.

There are treasure items scattered around some maps presumably looted by your enemies, treasure that you can loot back...or carry around in a magic bag, or simply destroy them on the spot seeing as there's no way B.J. can carry all that stuff around with him normally. However B.J. does it, getting treasure increases your score.

This along with the lives system are interesting parts of an otherwise straight-shooting game: indicators of a transition between the games of old and the games Wolf3D would end up inflencing even today.

The enemies you'll most often face are brown-uniformed pistol guards, machine gun-toting Schutzstaffel who wear blue uniforms for some reason, and German shepherds. You'll encounter white-clad, crack-shot officers and deadly mutants in the later episodes, both of which are enemies to watch out for.

What they lack in complexity of AI they make up for in numbers, positioning and individual tactical behavior, much like DOOM's enemies. At the end of every episode is a unique boss, and they range from a bit difficult to quite hard, and without strafing (Alt+movement with vanilla controls) they are impossible.

You'll have up to four weapons to choose from:

* semi-automatic knife - you have to fire once every time you want to attack with it, and you need to time stealth kills just right or hope you stun your target enough
* semi-automatic Luger - good for precise takedowns of weak enemies
* non-descript machine gun - pretty much your default weapon, good for taking out multiple targets and handfuls of stronger enemies
* non-descript ammo-eating chaingun - for those rooms just full of Nazi ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s

Compounding your weapon 'choices' are the fact that you can only carry 99 bullets.


The music is mostly decent, but while some of it is pretty good (for 1992 anyway) it loops fast and can get a bit grating after a while. Combined with the blank colored ceiling and floor, intently deployed scenery, labrynthine & abstracted maps with no automapping feature by default, 1992 sound effects, 'unique' game mechanics and often tense nature of gameplay, I meant it when the game can get difficult and surreal at times.

On the higher difficulty maps it's not uncommon for a single enemy to take a good chunk of your health off with one shot, to say nothing of an SS' machine gun or mutant attack. There are a good number of enemies on the later maps, you don't have any armor, and on some maps health itself can be hard to come by. And on some maps, opening fire on an enemy can alert most of the map's other enemies at the same time.

Fortunately, you have the aforementioned multiple life system...which is mostly rendered moot by your limitless and merciful ability to save anywhere.

The controls are not very configurable (in the base DOSBox version) and can take some getting used to. You can at least enable mouse movement, which I much prefer. If you want modern controls, the previously mentioned ECWolf sourceport lets you customize them - ECWolf also has the highest quality music and framerate you can get for this game.

While the game can be played at a fast pace, it is more common and usually prudent to take a cautious and slower approach, and there is ultimately more of an emphasis on tactics - positioning, luring and predicting enemies - than aiming ability (apart from capping unaware enemies) and dodging (what little of it you can do, anyway). You can still run and gun of course, but that's easier said than done sometimes, especially when compared with its successor Doom.


In fact, while this game is ostensibly macho, some of the situations you can find yourself in can be unnerving. You aren't always comfortably in control of situations, with lurking enemies that could kill you in seconds & map design that works against you, and this happens more and more in the later episodes. Wolfenstein 3-D is still ultimately a simple game at heart, but it does a lot with what it has. For more reading about this topic I recommend Liz Ryerson's writing about the game[ellaguro.blogspot.com].


So...is it worth playing after two decades? Well, I think so. See the very first paragraph for why. It's not for everyone, given its age and the way it plays, but for people who like old-school games, gaming history and/or really like shooting Nazis, I'd recommend it.

It's cheaper than The New Order, at least.

You navigate a series of mazes to find an elevator and any keys needed to open the doors that block it and are scored at the end of each based on your time, kills, and secrets found.  You're armed with a knife and the 3 guns you can pick up. (pistol, submachine gun, and Gatling-gun).  You can only carry 99 bullets so ammo is always a concern, especially since all your guns share the same rounds and the automatics burn them fast, but that's part of the game's core design.  Many secret passages contain guns and ammo but there's no hint to what walls open, so you just have to rub against them all.

CONTROLS:  You can turn left and right and also strafe by holding shift but you cannot look or aim vertically.  It doesn‚Äôt seem too picky about your horizontal accuracy either, you just aim in a Nazi‚Äôs general direction and drop them (good thing too since there‚Äôs no iron sight or crosshairs).

STORY:  Kill Nazis go!  You‚Äôre a captured spy and the game contains 6 episodes of 10 floors each.  Episode 1 has you tasked with escaping while the others have other objectives such as killing various madmen bosses, including Hitler.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein 3D is a game hailed by some as the grandfather of the First Person Shooter genre and ignored by others as simply a hiccup before Doom came out.

While it certainly was Doom that made the Genre popular Wolf3D still needs to be acknowledged for being the first. Before this it was all side scrolling and looking through the eyes of the protagonist simply wasn't an idea anyone had had yet.

The gameplay is extremely basic, even by the standards of the time. There is no looking up or down, everything takes place on the same level and you move in blocks, much like first person RPG's. The sound and graphics quality were decent enough for the day but would soon be shown up completely by the release of Doom.

The difficulty of it still holds some challenge today, particularly if you pick up some of the free map packs available and the bosses at the end of each level is truly a sight to behold. Mecha-Hitler will forever bring forth fond memories for me.

reviewText:
The big one.

This is the game that brought id into the lime light. Before Doom, Wolfenstein 3-D captivated players with impressive 3D enviroments for the time.

A lot of people say it hasn't aged well, but I think it has. It's a pretty fun game, but it can get boring. It's basically just the gameplay of Doom except you have lives and shoot Nazis and collect treasure. The levels are all flat planed dungeon/castle theme levels due to the limitations of the engine. There are no elevated surfaces and ceilings and floors have no texture. Still though, that doesn't mean it's bad. It may tire you after a while of play though.

All you have to do is get to the end of each level, but you really have to mind the nazis around you or you could be killed in literally one shot.

For it's time, Wolf 3D was groundbreaking. By today's standards, it can get boring at times, but it's still as fun as I remember playing it. If you don't want to shell the 4.99 for wolf 3d, you can download the Wolfenstein 3D Total Conversion for Doom 2.

Also, there appear to be a few other hardware incompatibilites that detract from the experience.  The sound playback seems to be incompatible with modern cards, leading to weird sound glitches (go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGc6UCyuyl8 to hear what it should sound like minus the modern voice over and gun SFX, then play and decide for yourself.)  Not sure if this is something wrong with my settings or a legitimate incompatibility with either my sound card or playback devices.

This is also a straight port, not revamped in any way.

To be honest, I had more fun playing the iPhone port which is free.  However, this version gets an 8/10 overall from me for pure nostalgia value and the fact that it was (and is) an amazing game and pioneer of the FPS genre.

10/10 One of the best franchises I've ever played. And the one that started it was amazing too.

Its a classic the reason why we have FPS today. Its a real good throw back if you looking for an old game that you can play to waste time. If you want a challenge try it on the harder difficulties. Just buy it, it is a classic!!!

If you're hankering for a bit of nostalgia, this is probably $5 well spent.

That said, this has a couple of issues, and these should be mentioned alongside the fact that I run Windows 8.1 64 bit.  There are options for mouse functionality that don't seem to work, leaving you to navigate and fight with keyboard only as you did back when this game was released.  Granted, that's the way it's meant to be played, but after a decade of a more polished experience it feels a bit clunky.  Also, there appear to be a few other hardware incompatibilites that detract from the experience.  The sound playback seems to be incompatible with modern cards, leading to weird sound glitches (go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGc6UCyuyl8 to hear what it should sound like minus the modern voice over and gun SFX, then play and decide for yourself.)  Not sure if this is something wrong with my settings or a legitimate incompatibility with either my sound card or playback devices.

This is also a straight port, not revamped in any way.

To be honest, I had more fun playing the iPhone port which is free.  However, this version gets an 8/10 overall from me for pure nostalgia value and the fact that it was (and is) an amazing game and pioneer of the FPS genre.

EDIT: Not sure if they've patched this since my original review, or if the upgrade to Windows 10 is the cause, but the sound issues are much less noticeable.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein 3D is pure old school shooter fun. While the game features a few tricky levels, for the most part it is smartly designed to deliver maximum Nazi killing fun. It might be old, but this game's still got some bite to it.

As one of the shooters that helped put id Software on the map, it is a piece of gaming history. And hey, it's one of the few World War 2 FPSes where you actually get to fight Adolf Hitler himself!

No checkpoints, no autosaves. Just lots of bullets and Nazis to blow away. While some of the later levels can lead to some hair pulling by hiding important keys and items behind hidden walls and also becoming more maze like, the designs for the most part work well at letting you find your way without getting lost.

reviewText:
The great-grandad of the FPS genre.

Yeah, it's alright. I didn't like it too much.

I know, I'm a horrid person, aren't I?

So far, I've only played a couple of id games, and unfortunately this is the first one I didn't really enjoy. DOOM was like a blast of cocaine, and Return to Castle Wolfenstein was like a slightly less better version than Half-Life that I still appreciated. But this? Well... it's just kind of nothing.

In Wolfenstein 3D, you follow a similar pattern of old-school gaming platforms that loosely tie a story together as you go and kill more and more enemies (which in this game's case is Nazis). So, most of the issues I have instantly fall towards gameplay. I will say this though, this game has NOT aged well, especially for its controls. I spent a while reconfiguring them for mouse input, but at that point, I could move around by moving the mouse. And the A and D made you look- not strafe- right and left, which was really irritating at certain points.

The levels are pretty simple- find the key, kill the Nazis- but their structure definitely isn't. These maze-like dungeous kept me stuck for nearly 20 minutes, just trying to find my way out of one corridor, because all the hallways in this game look the same. Yes, there are deviations of color, but in those specific areas, everything looks the same! It's incredibly easy to start losing your head as you run in constant circles around the same places again and again and again...

DOOM aged much easier, since it allowed actually understandable controls and gameplay that anyone could adapt to, with some relatively posh level design. Does that make Wolfenstein 3D a good foundation? Certainly. But does that make it a good game? Frankly no.

reviewText:
This is going to be an odd review, for the reason that I will mostly be reviewing this game with the idea that one is playing with a mod to polish this game a little bit, as the steam version feels very blurry and dated, and makes this game feel a lot less timeless than it really is. If you end up buying this game anyway, and try the mod I recommend, it's a good idea to view this as the 2D maze-like puzzle game where you have some sort of fog-of-war, because most can relate to a retro game rather than viewing this with the same standards of call of duty. This game has one serious flaw, and it's that you almost can't play the original version that steam sells.

The mod I recommend here is called ZDOOM, and while it's for Doom, it can be used for this game with a few tweaks. Overall it makes this game feel less like it did in 1992, and gives it the polished feel of a retro game made in the 80's that everyone can play, like Mario. ZDOOM fixes polishing issues in the game, such as resolution fixes, mouse and keyboard if you wish (even though I don't recommend it), texture fixes, and overall gameplay fixes that make this game a lot more timeless while still keeping the original atmosphere. I usually strongly dislike revamping old games (for example, SkyWind makes me cringe), but this fixes key issues that make this game not fun, while stuff like SkyWind just makes the game pretty, killing its original atmosphere and feel of the game.

Now that I've discussed how to be able to play this game with minimal frustrations, I'm going to be straightforward and tell you this is not a good game. I have about 15 hours off steam on this game, and based on my experiences, this game still has some serious problems that can't be fixed with something like ZDOOM. It's really obvious that this game is dated as hell, as it was the grandfather of FPS. You'd really think it's not that bad, but it is. It's a truly unplayable game when you get down to it; it's just not fun. A pros and cons list would be a good way to show this game's worth since ratings for games can be pretty subjective.

Pros:
- Managable fighting mechanics, ZDOOM gives this game simple controls and easy-to-learn combat. At first I didn't enjoy keyboard controls, but this game's map design really gives an interesting idea with it. The fact that you have to turn left and right does add a bit of challenge since the devs like putting enemies on both sides, and gives strategies that also include a mix of strafing (with alt key), and add a little more extra fun to the table, and trust me, you need that extra fun.
- Has creative map layout at points, and the maps that try to be memorable (like secret levels, bosses, and aardwolf maze) are very memorable and I could still point them out. The did some interesting choices with the actual combat itself, and gives a more fun idea of fighting that really gives strategy. Like Doom, this game is known for having some serious consequences for not thinking and responding fast, and really gives some emotion out of the game.
- Pretty playable, it's easy to beat a chapter in a day since missions are short and the game can be not enjoyable or bad, but just generic, so you can sometimes play a lot.
- Uses an atmosphere and a premise of why you're fighting rather than a linear story, so you can get right into the action rather than having a boring, linear game with no thought put in yourself.
- Better mechanics than a lot of modern games (difficulty in this game has more factors for it than Skyrim, and gives some variety there)
- There's fun in the idea that there are a lot of modders that add their own flavor to some of the maps, and create their own original weapons and maps, and it's fun to play at least a couple. I'll send one to start with at the bottom of the review.

Cons:
- 4 types of enemies, most chapters don't show all at once. This really kills a lot of the fun, because it's just you doing the same thing over, and over, and over again, and I can understand that this game was made in 1992, but it just lacks polish for such a big game.
- The normal levels really aren't memorable and it just seems like there lacks care in the level design, everything is bland and the same, and it's nothing exciting for so long.
- Generic weapons that do the same amounts of damage and use the same ammo, just have different fire rates.
- Can feel a bit clunky at times with movement, and looking around.
- Overall a generic game, nothing seems exciting, and some points you just get so bored you quit and don't play the game for the rest of the day. All of the missions feel like the same thing over and over again, there's no interesting gun variety, no enemy variety, no variety for any factors in this game, even health and ammo drops are the same over and over again. I'd really say that doesn't make this game bad, but it's just not exciting. It would be different if there were a small amount of weapons but each were very unique, but each small variety of items adds nothing new to the table and feels the same as the last. If you're dealing with small variety and blandness, there's not only no content, but no fun with it, and that's just done poorly.

Overall, I'd really say this game isn't terrible, but it lacks map, weapon, enemy, health, and ammo variety, and ends up feeling like the same game over and over again. I'd personally recommend this over modern day Call of Duty because they're essentially the same game; a generic game with nothing really new or exciting in it. This game is somewhat timeless with ZDOOM, but movement can feel seriously clunky at times and it's just more of not fun" than a "dated" or "hard" game with today's standards. If you're one to enjoy FPS and don't really care about variety then this game would be playable and pretty interesting to play

Wolfenstein 3D is the grandfather of all first-person shooters.

Pros: Classic
Cons: Graphics, Sounds, Controls, Gameplay, Repetitive

No other game had fully realized an environment and atmosphere so immersive that players could forget they were playing a game.

My recommendation is to play Wolfenstein 3D online under Bethesda's official release.  Specifically, play the third episode and fight against the first hordes of Nazi zombies and Mecha Hitler.  id Software has released Wolfenstein: The New Order, so if you appreciate the impact the company has had on the industry, you can support them by buying that instead.

It is incredibly tough, but not unfairly so- all the resources you need are in the level, with yet more hidden. Level design is a bit archaic- at times it's really just a maze, and the samey wall textures don't help- but learning the maps, finding secrets and paying attention to your surroundings will reward you greatly. Enemy soldiers are unforgiving and have very fast reaction times that you will have to beat to survive, and at times there will be very many of them. Wolfenstein 3D still has something to offer modern games who are looking for a bit of nostalgia. Although this wasn't the first FPS, it was the first blockbuster hit that really established the FPS as a genre. However, the game doesn't hold up very well today.

Wolfenstein 3D is fun, but also very frustrating. Here are a few problems. 1) The controls are so atrocious that the game is practically unplayable, but a source port program like ECWolf can be used to update the control scheme. 2) The layout of levels is sprawling, and the blocky and repetitive architecture give most levels an annoying maze-like feel. 3) The game is weird with corners, meaning that sometimes enemies can see and shoot you around a corner, but you can't see them. 4) The mutant enemy type will often shoot you instantaneously on sight, without you having time to react. 5) There are only a few types of weapons and enemies, and combat quickly becomes repetitive. 6) The built-in auto-aim can be clunky and unreliable.

Ultimately, I recommend Wolfenstein 3D because it is still fun to play despite its many failings, which admittedly will keep some FPS fans from enjoying it. My advice is to play it with the ECWolf source port (or another like it), and to enjoy the game in small doses, playing a level or two per day so that it won't become tedious. If you want some nostalgia and can appreciate an older game in spite of its limitations, then Wolfenstein 3D is a good buy.

Sure, as I said before, the graphics are dated and it looks like a mess someone drew in MS Paint compared to pretty much anything since then. Wolfenstein 3D has a lot of flaws in 2015 that weren't really apparent back in 1992. The levels are repetetive mazes that are easy to get lost in and theres no map which worsens the issue. The controls by default are clunky and hard to use (though this is fixable but not on this release alone, a source port will fix this) the game is unfairly difficult, the list goes on.

The shooting is very fun and the 3 guns that you get in the game are all fun to use. Especially the chaingun with its loud sounds and sheer power. Killing things is really fun in this game thanks to great sound effects, good hit detection and good animation. The game is fun, but it hasn't exactly aged well, but if you can tolerate its problems Wolfenstein 3D is still a fun game. If anything you should buy for its historical importance.

The visuals are basic, no surprise there, but they don't look bad. The sprites are very detailed and the textures look good. The textures do tend to repeat and the levels are complex in design but basic in look. There are no multileveled floors, the levels are flat and static, but again this game was released in 1992 so its okay.

Overall I recommend this game only if you know if you are getting into. Wolfenstein 3D. A first-person action game developed by id Software in 1994. This game is often known as one of the pioneers for the First Person Shooter genre, pushing it towards what it has become today. It drew inspiration from the old 1980‚Äôs Castle Wolfenstein games. Wolfenstein 3D put players in the first person perspective and let you run around several levels, shooting Nazis.

Wolfenstein 3D was originally developed for Dos PCs. Back in the day it used the common shareware marketing model that let people play the first episode for free. It has since been re-released and ported to several gaming systems and mobile platforms.

-Story
As with alot of action games at the time, Wolfenstein 3D had a very simple story. You play as William Blazkowicz as you try to take down the Nazi regime. The original game was split up into 3 episodes, having the player work their way through a series of levels, wandering through buildings and caves as you shoot at Nazis, Dogs and Zombies. You had simple goals like escaping a prison, foiling the Regime's plans, and coming to a final confrontation with the Fuhrer himself.

Later releases included the three episode prequel, the Nocturnal Missions, that dealt with German plans for chemical warfare. A Standalone Expansion, The Spear of Destiny, was also a prequel that tasked the player with reclaiming the Spear of Destiny from the Nazis.

-Design:
As a First Person Action Shooter that was developed in the early 90‚Äôs, the graphics may be primitive by today's standards, but back in the day compared to other 3D games of the time, the 3d walls and sprites combined with the faster movement blew minds away. Castle and cave walls made up most of the environment that were littered with sprites of furniture, water puddles and enemies. While there is a lot of Nazi imagery in the game, later versions had some alterations such as removing swastikas due to controversy.

The game is divided up into episodes consisting of 9 levels each, as well as a secret level to find. Level design was quite extravagant with several branching paths. It was often like a maze as you tried to find the exit door, coming across some doors that required special keys you needed to find. There are also several secrets hidden throughout, usually behind pushwalls,  with goodies such as gold, ammo, health and sometimes a new weapon. Spear of destiny broke from the episode format by just having a series of 18 levels split into four sections, each ending with a boss.

Gameplay wise, it was a good advancement from other first person titles at the time. For several players tho, the controls may be hard to get used to, with the key configuration being a little awkward. If you want a better experience, I suggest installing a 3rd party engine such as ECWolf, which will allow modern key configuration and higher resolutions. If you prefer to use a controller, the XBLA and PSN versions will work as you expect.

-Verdict:
Wolfenstein 3D is a nice piece of gaming history that put the FPS genre in the direction that it ended up in today. If you can look past the primitive graphics and like to get to know where shooters came from, it is a great buy for $5 on Steam, XBLA and PSN. Or if you need a nice diversion while you're out, $2 on the iTunes app store.

Wolfenstein 3D. A first-person action game developed by id Software in 1994. This game is often known as one of the pioneers for the First Person Shooter genre, pushing it towards what it has become today. It drew inspiration from the old 1980‚Äôs Castle Wolfenstein games. Wolfenstein 3D put players in the first person perspective and let you run around several levels, shooting Nazis.

Wolfenstein 3D was originally developed for Dos PCs. Back in the day it used the common shareware marketing model that let people play the first episode for free. It has since been re-released and ported to several gaming systems and mobile platforms.

-Story
As with alot of action games at the time, Wolfenstein 3D had a very simple story. You play as William Blazkowicz as you try to take down the Nazi regime. The original game was split up into 3 episodes, having the player work their way through a series of levels, wandering through buildings and caves as you shoot at Nazis, Dogs and Zombies. You had simple goals like escaping a prison, foiling the Regime's plans, and coming to a final confrontation with the Fuhrer himself.

Later releases included the three episode prequel, the Nocturnal Missions, that dealt with German plans for chemical warfare. A Standalone Expansion, The Spear of Destiny, was also a prequel that tasked the player with reclaiming the Spear of Destiny from the Nazis.

-Design:
As a First Person Action Shooter that was developed in the early 90‚Äôs, the graphics may be primitive by today's standards, but back in the day compared to other 3D games of the time, the 3d walls and sprites combined with the faster movement blew minds away. Castle and cave walls made up most of the environment that were littered with sprites of furniture, water puddles and enemies. While there is a lot of Nazi imagery in the game, later versions had some alterations such as removing swastikas due to controversy.

The game is divided up into episodes consisting of 9 levels each, as well as a secret level to find. Level design was quite extravagant with several branching paths. It was often like a maze as you tried to find the exit door, coming across some doors that required special keys you needed to find. There are also several secrets hidden throughout, usually behind pushwalls,  with goodies such as gold, ammo, health and sometimes a new weapon. Spear of destiny broke from the episode format by just having a series of 18 levels split into four sections, each ending with a boss.

Gameplay wise, it was a good advancement from other first person titles at the time. For several players tho, the controls may be hard to get used to, with the key configuration being a little awkward. If you want a better experience, I suggest installing a 3rd party engine such as ECWolf, which will allow modern key configuration and higher resolutions. If you prefer to use a controller, the XBLA and PSN versions will work as you expect.

-Verdict:
Wolfenstein 3D is a nice piece of gaming history that put the FPS genre in the direction that it ended up in today. If you can look past the primitive graphics and like to get to know where shooters came from, it is a great buy for $5 on Steam, XBLA and PSN. Or if you need a nice diversion while you're out, $2 on the iTunes app store.

For as far as shooters have come, they can still be boiled down to their fundamentals. Shooting and navigating levels. Wolfenstein 3D set the groundwork for a genre that hasn't ceased being the most popular in the world. If you enjoy shooters in any capacity, you owe it to Wolfenstein 3D for popularizing them.

Does the game hold up in the modern era? Yes and no. No in that it's incredibly simplistic. It's nice to have something with such a clear goal, but playing through a single episode is all it takes to see the entirety of Wolfenstein 3D's bag of tricks. Other than different boss characters and one new enemy, you can fully understand this game in about 30 minutes.

The level designs start off fairly obtuse, but get refined as the game progresses. The prequel episodes, for instance, are very concise and fast. Things are laid out in a more logical fashion and the levels don't take more than 5 minutes (save for a few agonizing levels in Episode 6). The earlier levels suffer from being sprawling and lacking definition in their textures.

The weapons are definitely limited, but it's cool to have everything utilize the same ammo. Whatever weapon you decide to go with is more like an optional challenge than anything. Trying to knife everyone may be futile, but it can be done. Getting that gattling gun is like putting the game on Easy mode, so it's hard to not default to it.

As for the boss battles, they range from hilariously easy to pure ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t. The first boss is a push over (and he comes back for Episode 5), but taking on Hitler is a different story. He has hit-scan weapons that basically hit you with 100% accuracy. He also has floating magicians and a second form. It's insane.

Some of the levels are also overloaded with enemies. You start off with basically a pistol and have no possible way to take them on, unless you are astute enough to find the secrets. Secrets were basically half the game back in the day, so it's not hard to understand why valuable items were placed there.

What isn't acceptable is how some necessary keys and a few exits are stuck behind secrets". That is just cruel. I guess level design standards were more based on finding secrets back in 1992
